codelists.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale test code.
codelists.name: QS-Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale Test Code
codelists.preferredTerm: CDISC Questionnaire HAMA Test Code Terminology
synonyms: QS-Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale Test Code

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Anxious mood: worries, anticipation of the worst, fearful anticipation, irritability.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Anxious Mood

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Tension: feelings of tension, fatigability, startle response, moved to tears easily, trembling, feelings of restlessness, inability to relax.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Tension

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Fears: of dark, of strangers, of being left alone, of animals, of traffic, of crowds.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Fears

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Insomnia: difficulty falling asleep, broken sleep, unsatisfying sleep and fatigue on waking, dreams, nightmares, night terrors.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Insomnia

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Intellectual: difficulty in concentration, poor memory.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Intellectual

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Depressed mood: loss of interest, lack of pleasure in hobbies, depression, early waking, diurnal swing.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Depressed Mood

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Somatic (muscular): pains and aches, twitching, stiffness, myoclonic jerks, grinding of teeth, unsteady voice, increased muscular tone.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Somatic (Muscular)

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Somatic (sensory): tinnitus, blurring of vision, hot and cold flushes, feelings of weakness, pricking sensation.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Somatic (Sensory)

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Cardiovascular symptoms: tachycardia, palpitations, pain in chest, throbbing of vessels, fainting feelings, missing beat.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Cardiovascular Symptoms

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Respiratory symptoms: pressure or constriction in chest, choking feelings, sighing, dyspnea.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Respiratory Symptoms

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Gastrointestinal symptoms: difficulty swallowing, wind abdominal pain, burning sensations, abdominal fullness, nausea, vomiting, borborygmi, looseness of bowels, loss of weight, constipation.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Gastrointestinal Symptoms

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Genitourinary symptoms: frequency of micturition, urgency of micturition, amenorrhea, menorrhagia, development of frigidity, premature ejaculation, loss of libido, impotence.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Genitourinary Symptoms

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Autonomic symptoms: dry mouth, flushing, pallor, tendency to sweat, giddiness, tension, headache, raising of hair.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Autonomic Symptoms

terms.definition: Hamilton Anxiety Rating Scale - Behavior at interview: fidgeting, restlessness or pacing, tremor of hands, furrowed brow, strained face, sighing or rapid respiration, facial pallor, swallowing, etc.
terms.preferredTerm: HAMA - Behavior at Interview

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems walking or moving; balance problems that interfere with moving about.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Mobility

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Impaired strength or coordination in one or both hands.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Use of Hands

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems seeing; double vision; eye, brain, or nerve injuries that interfere with seeing.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Vision

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems hearing; ringing in the ears.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Audition

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Feeling unsteady, dizzy, light-headed.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Dizziness

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Abnormal clearness or rate of speech; stuttering.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Motor Speech

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems expressing or understanding language.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Verbal Communication

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Restricted or unusual gestures or facial expressions; talking too much or not enough; missing nonverbal cues from others.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Nonverbal Communication

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems ignoring distractions, shifting attention, keeping more than one thing in mind at a time.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Attention or Concentration

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems learning and recalling new information.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Memory

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems remembering information learned in school or on the job; difficulty remembering information about self and family from years ago.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Fund of Information

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems thinking up solutions or picking the best solution to new problems.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Novel Problem-Solving

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems drawing, assembling things, route-finding, being visually aware on both the left and right sides.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Visuospatial Abilities

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Tense, nervous, fearful, phobias, nightmares, flashbacks of stressful events.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Anxiety

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Sad, blue, hopeless, poor appetite, poor sleep, worry, self-criticism.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Depression

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Verbal or physical expressions of anger.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Irritability, Anger, Aggression

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Verbal and nonverbal expressions of pain; activities limited by pain.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Pain and Headache

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Feeling tired; lack of energy; tiring easily.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Fatigue

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Focusing on thinking, physical or emotional problems attributed to brain injury; rate only how concern or worry about these symptoms affects current functioning over and above the effects of the symptoms themselves.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Sensitivity to Mild Symptoms

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Acting childish, silly, rude, behavior not fitting for time and place.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Inappropriate Social Interaction

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Lack of recognition of personal limitations and disabilities and how they interfere with everyday activities and work or school.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Impaired Self-Awareness

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Interactions with close others; describe stress within the family or those closest to the person with brain injury; 'family functioning' means cooperating to accomplish those tasks that need to be done to keep the household running.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Family or Significant Relationships

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems getting started on activities without prompting.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Initiation

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Social contact with friends, work associates, and other people who are not family, significant others, or professionals.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Social Contact with Fiends, Work Associates and Others

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Leisure and recreational activities.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Leisure and Recreational Activities

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Eating, dressing, bathing, hygiene.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Self-Care

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Responsibilities of independent living and homemaking (such as meal preparation, home repairs and maintenance, personal health maintenance beyond basic hygiene including medication management) but not including managing money.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Residence

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Transportation.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Transportation

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Hours per week at paid employment when primary desired social role is paid employment. 'Support' means special help from another person with responsibilities (such as, a job coach or shadow, tutor, helper) or reduced responsibilities. Modifications to the physical environment that facilitate employment are not considered as support.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Paid Employment

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Hours per week involved in constructive, role-appropriate activity other than paid employment when primary desired social role is not paid employment. 'Support' means special help from another person with responsibilities (such as, a job coach or shadow, tutor, helper) or reduced responsibilities. Modifications to the physical environment that facilitate employment are not considered as support.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Other Employment

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Primary social role when paid employment is not primary desired social role.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Other Employment-Social Role

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Shopping, keeping a check book or other bank account, managing personal income and investments.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Managing Money and Finances

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Pre-injury use of alcoholic beverages.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Alcohol Use Pre-Injury

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Post-injury use of alcoholic beverages.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Alcohol Use Post-Injury

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Pre-injury use of illegal drugs or abuse of prescription drugs.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Drug Use Pre-Injury

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Post-injury use of illegal drugs or abuse of prescription drugs.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Drug Use Post-Injury

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Pre-injury hallucinations, delusions, other persistent severely distorted perceptions of reality.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Psychotic Symptoms Pre-Injury

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Post-injury hallucinations, delusions, other persistent severely distorted perceptions of reality.

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Post-injury history before and after injury.

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Post-injury physical disability due to medical conditions other than brain injury, such as, spinal cord injury, amputation.

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems remembering information learned in school or on the job; difficulty remembering information about self and family from years ago.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Fund of Information

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Lack of recognition of personal limitations and disabilities and how they interfere with everyday activities and work or school.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Impaired Self-Awareness

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Acting childish, silly, rude, behavior not fitting for time and place.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Inappropriate Social Interaction

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems getting started on activities without prompting.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Initiation

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Verbal or physical expressions of anger.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Irritability, Anger, Aggression

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Post-injury history before and after injury.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Law Violations Post-Injury

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Pre-injury history before and after injury.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Law Violations Pre-Injury

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Leisure and recreational activities.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Leisure and Recreational Activities

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Shopping, keeping a check book or other bank account, managing personal income and investments.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Managing Money and Finances

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems learning and recalling new information.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Memory

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems walking or moving; balance problems that interfere with moving about.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Mobility

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Abnormal clearness or rate of speech; stuttering.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Motor Speech

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Restricted or unusual gestures or facial expressions; talking too much or not enough; missing nonverbal cues from others.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Nonverbal Communication

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems thinking up solutions or picking the best solution to new problems.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Novel Problem-Solving

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Post-injury cognitive disability due to nonpsychiatric medical conditions other than brain injury, such as, dementia, stroke, developmental disability.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Other Condition Causing Cognitive Impairment Post-Injury

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Pre-injury cognitive disability due to nonpsychiatric medical conditions other than brain injury, such as, dementia, stroke, developmental disability.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Other Condition Causing Cognitive Impairment Pre-Injury

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Hours per week involved in constructive, role-appropriate activity other than paid employment when primary desired social role is not paid employment. 'Support' means special help from another person with responsibilities (such as, a job coach or shadow, tutor, helper) or reduced responsibilities. Modifications to the physical environment that facilitate employment are not considered as support.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Other Employment

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Primary social role when paid employment is not primary desired social role.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Other Employment-Social Role

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Post-injury physical disability due to medical conditions other than brain injury, such as, spinal cord injury, amputation.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Other Condition Causing Physical Impairment Post-Injury

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Pre-injury physical disability due to medical conditions other than brain injury, such as, spinal cord injury, amputation.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Other Condition Causing Physical Impairment Pre-Injury

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Hours per week at paid employment when primary desired social role is paid employment. 'Support' means special help from another person with responsibilities (such as, a job coach or shadow, tutor, helper) or reduced responsibilities. Modifications to the physical environment that facilitate employment are not considered as support.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Paid Employment

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Verbal and nonverbal expressions of pain; activities limited by pain.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Pain and Headache

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Post-injury hallucinations, delusions, other persistent severely distorted perceptions of reality.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Psychotic Symptoms Post-Injury

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Pre-injury hallucinations, delusions, other persistent severely distorted perceptions of reality.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Psychotic Symptoms Pre-Injury

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Responsibilities of independent living and homemaking (such as meal preparation, home repairs and maintenance, personal health maintenance beyond basic hygiene including medication management) but not including managing money.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Residence

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Eating, dressing, bathing, hygiene.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Self-Care

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Focusing on thinking, physical or emotional problems attributed to brain injury; rate only how concern or worry about these symptoms affects current functioning over and above the effects of the symptoms themselves.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Adjustment: Sensitivity to Mild Symptoms

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Social contact with friends, work associates, and other people who are not family, significant others, or professionals.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Social Contact with Fiends, Work Associates and Others

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Transportation.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Participation: Transportation

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Impaired strength or coordination in one or both hands.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Use of Hands

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems expressing or understanding language.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Verbal Communication

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems seeing; double vision; eye, brain, or nerve injuries that interfere with seeing.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Vision

terms.definition: Mayo-Portland Adaptability Inventory-4 - Problems drawing, assembling things, route-finding, being visually aware on both the left and right sides.
terms.preferredTerm: MPAI-4 - Abilities: Visuospatial Abilities

terms.definition: National Eye Institute Visual Functioning Questionnaire - 25 Version 2000 Self-Administered Format - Responses to Vision Problems: I have much less control over what I do, because of my eyesight.
terms.preferredTerm: VFQ25-Self Administered Format - Have Less Control Because of Eyesight
terms.submissionValue: VFQ2-Much Less Control Over What I Do
synonyms: VFQ2-Much Less Control Over What I Do

terms.definition: National Eye Institute Visual Functioning Questionnaire - 25 Version 2000 Self-Administered Format - Difficulty With Activities: If no: Have you never driven a car or have you given up driving?
terms.preferredTerm: VFQ25-Self Administered Format - Never Driven or Given Up Driving
terms.submissionValue: VFQ2-Never Driven or Given Up Driving
synonyms: VFQ2-Never Driven or Given Up Driving

terms.definition: National Eye Institute Visual Functioning Questionnaire - 25 Version 2000 Self-Administered Format - Well-Being/Distress: I am often irritable because of my eyesight.
terms.preferredTerm: VFQ25-Self Administered Format - Often Irritable Because of Eyesight

terms.definition: National Eye Institute Visual Functioning Questionnaire - 25 Version 2000 Self-Administered Format - General Vision: How would you rate your eyesight now (with glasses or contact lens on, if you wear them), on a scale of from 0 to 10, where zero means the worst possible eyesight, as bad or worse than being blind, and 10 means the best possible eyesight?
terms.preferredTerm: VFQ25-Self Administered Format - Rate Your Eyesight Now

terms.definition: National Eye Institute Visual Functioning Questionnaire - 25 Version 2000 Self-Administered Format - General Health: How would you rate your overall health, on a scale where zero is as bad as death and 10 is best possible health?
terms.preferredTerm: VFQ25-Self Administered Format - Rate Your Overall Health

terms.definition: National Eye Institute Visual Functioning Questionnaire - 25 Version 2000 Self-Administered Format - Responses to Vision Problems: Because of my eyesight, I have to rely too much on what other people tell me.
terms.preferredTerm: VFQ25-Self Administered Format - Have to Rely On Other People Because of Eyesight
terms.submissionValue: VFQ2-Rely Too Much on What Others Tell
synonyms: VFQ2-Rely Too Much on What Others Tell

terms.definition: National Eye Institute Visual Functioning Questionnaire - 25 Version 2000 Self-Administered Format - Responses to Vision Problems: I worry about doing things that will embarrass myself or others, because of my eyesight.
terms.preferredTerm: VFQ25-Self Administered Format - Worry About Embarrass Myself or Others Because of Eyesight

terms.definition: National Eye Institute Visual Functioning Questionnaire - 25 Version 2000 Self-Administered Format - General Health and Vision: In general, would you say your overall health is:
terms.preferredTerm: VFQ25-Self Administered Format - Overall Health

codelists.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale test code.
codelists.name: QS-Neuropathic Pain Scale Questionnaire Test Code
codelists.preferredTerm: CDISC Questionnaire NPS Test Code Terminology
synonyms: QS-Neuropathic Pain Scale Questionnaire Test Code

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - Please use the scale below to tell us how intense your pain is.
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - Tell Us How Intense Your Pain Is
synonyms: NPS01-Tell Us How Intense Your Pain Is

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - Please use the scale below to tell us how sharp your pain feels. Words used to describe 'sharp' feelings include 'like a knife,' 'like a spike,' 'jabbing,' or 'like jolts.'
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - Tell Us How Sharp Your Pain Feels
synonyms: NPS01-Tell Us How Sharp Your Pain Feels

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - Please use the scale below to tell us how hot your pain feels. Words used to describe very hot pain include 'burning' and 'on fire.'
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - Tell Us How Hot Your Pain Feels
synonyms: NPS01-Tell Us How Hot Your Pain Feels

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - Please use the scale below to tell us how dull your pain feels. Words used to describe very dull pain include 'like a dull toothache,' 'dull pain,' and 'like a bruise.'
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - Tell Us How Dull Your Pain Feels
synonyms: NPS01-Tell Us How Dull Your Pain Feels

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - Please use the scale below to tell us how cold your pain feels. Words used to describe very cold pain included 'like ice' and 'freezing.'
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - Tell Us How Cold Your Pain Feels
synonyms: NPS01-Tell Us How Cold Your Pain Feels

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - Please use the scale below to tell us how sensitive your skin is to light touch or clothing. Words used to describe sensitive skin include 'like sunburned skin,' and 'raw skin.'
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - Tell Us How Sensitive Your Skin is to Light Touch or Clothing

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - Please use the scale below to tell us how itchy your pain feels. Words used to describe itchy pain include 'like poison oak' and 'like a mosquito bite.'
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - Tell Us How Itchy Your Pain Feels
synonyms: NPS01-Tell Us How Itchy Your Pain Feels

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - Which of the following best describes the time quality of your pain? Please check only one answer.
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - Describe the Time Quality Of Your Pain
synonyms: NPS01-Describe Time Quality Of Your Pain

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - I feel a background pain all of the time and occasional flare-ups (break-through pain) some of the time. Describe the background pain.
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - Describe the Background Pain

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - I feel a background pain all of the time and occasional flare-ups (break-through pain) some of the time. Describe the flare-up (break-through) pain.
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - Describe the Flare-up Pain

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - I feel a single type of pain all the time. Describe this pain.
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - Describe the Single Type of Pain All Time
synonyms: NPS01-Describe Single Type Pain All Time

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - I fee a single type of pain only sometimes. Other times, I am pain free. Describe the occasional pain.
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - Describe the Occasional Pain

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - Now that you have told us the different physical aspects of your pain, the different types of sensations, we want you to tell us overall how unpleasant your pain is to you. Words used to describe very unpleasant pain include 'miserable' and intolerable.' Remember, pain can have a low intensity, buy still feel extremely unpleasant, and some kinds of pain can have a high intensity but be very tolerable. With this scale, please tell us how unpleasant your pain feels.
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - Tell Us Overall How Unpleasant Your Pain is to You
synonyms: NPS01-Tell How Unpleasant Your Pain Feel

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - Lastly, we want you to give us an estimate of the severity of your deep versus surface pain. We want your to rate each location of pain separately. We realize that it can be difficult to make these estimates, and most likely it will be a 'best guess,' but please give us your best estimate. How intense is your deep pain?
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - How Intense is Your Deep Pain
synonyms: NPS01-How Intense is Your Deep Pain

terms.definition: Neuropathic Pain Scale - Lastly, we want you to give us an estimate of the severity of your deep versus surface pain. We want your to rate each location of pain separately. We realize that it can be difficult to make these estimates, and most likely it will be a 'best guess,' but please give us your best estimate. How intense is your surface pain?
terms.preferredTerm: NPS - How Intense is Your Surface Pain
synonyms: NPS01-How Intense is Your Surface Pain

codelists.preferredTerm: CDISC Questionnaire NPS Test Name Terminology
synonyms: QS-Neuropathic Pain Scale Questionnaire Test Name

codelists.definition: The Neuropsychiatric Inventory test code.
codelists.name: QS-Neuropsychiatric Inventory Test Code
codelists.preferredTerm: CDISC Questionnaire NPI Test Code Terminology

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have beliefs that you know are not true? (for example, insisting that people are trying to harm him/her or steal from him/her)? Has he/she said that family members are not who they say they are or that the house is not their home? I'm not asking about mere suspiciousness; I am interested if the patient is convinced that these things are happening to him/her.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Have Beliefs That You Know are Not True

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that he/she is in danger - that others are planning to hurt him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - He/She is in Danger

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that others are stealing from him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Others are Stealing From Him/Her

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that his/her spouse is having an affair?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - His/Her Spouse is Having an Affair

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that unwelcome guests are living in his/her house?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Unwelcome Guests are Living in His/Her House

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that his/her spouse or others are not who they claim to be?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - His/Her Spouse or Others Are Not Who They Claim To Be

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that his/her house is not his/her home?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - His/Her House Is Not His/Her Home

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that family members plan to abandon him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Family Members Plan to Abandon Him/Her

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that television or magazine figures are actually present in the home? (Does he/she try to talk or interact with them?)
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Television or Magazine Figures Are Actually Present In the Home

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe any other unusual things that I haven't asked about?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Unusual Things That I Haven't Asked About

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the delusions.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Delusions Frequency

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the delusions.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Delusions Severity

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Delusions Distress

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Delusions: (frequency score x severity score).
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Delusions FxS Score

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have hallucinations such as seeing false visions or hearing false voices? Does he/she seem to see, hear or experience things that are not present? By this question we do not mean just mistaken beliefs such as stating that someone who has died is still alive; rather we are asking if the patient actually has abnormal experiences of sounds or visions.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Hallucinations Such as Seeing False Visions or Hearing False Voices

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe hearing voices or act as if he/she hears voices?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Hearing Voices or Act as if He/She Hears Voices

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient talk to people who are not there?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk to People Who Are Not There

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe seeing things not seen by others or behave as if he/she is seeing things not seen by others (people, animals, lights, etc.)?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Seeing Things Not Seen by Others
synonyms: NPI1-See Things Not Seen by Others

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient report smelling odors not smelled by others?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Report Smelling Odors Not Smelled by Others
synonyms: NPI1-Smell Odors Others Do Not Smell

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe feeling things on his/her skin or otherwise appear to be feeling things crawling or touching him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Feeling Things on His/Her Skin

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe tastes that are without any known cause?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Tastes That Are Without Any Known Cause

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe any other unusual sensory experiences?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Any Other Unusual Sensory Experiences

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the hallucinations.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Hallucinations Frequency

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the hallucinations.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Hallucinations Severity

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Hallucinations Distress

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Hallucinations: (frequency score x severity score).
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Hallucinations FxS Score

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods when he/she refuses to cooperate or won't let people help him/her? Is he/she hard to handle?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods When He/She Refuses to Cooperate

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient get upset with those trying to care for him/her or resist activities such as bathing or changing clothes?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Get Upset with Those Trying to Care for Him/Her

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient stubborn, having to have things his/her way?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Stubborn

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient uncooperative, resistive to help from others?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Uncooperative

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have any other behaviors that make him/her hard to handle?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Behaviors That Make Him/Her Hard to Handle

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient shout or curse angrily?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Shout or Curse Angrily

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient slam doors, kick furniture, throw things?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Slam doors, Kick Furniture, Throw Things

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient attempt to hurt or hit others?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Attempt to Hurt or Hit Others

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have any other aggressive or agitated behaviors?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Aggressive or Agitated Behaviors

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the agitation/aggression.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Agitation/Aggression Frequency

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the agitation/aggression.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Agitation/Aggression Severity

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Agitation/Aggression Distress

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Agitation/Aggression: (frequency score x severity score).
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Agitation/Aggression FxS Score

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem sad or depressed? Does he/she say that he/she feels sad or depressed?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem Sad or Depressed

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods of tearfulness or sobbing that seem to indicate sadness?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods of Tearfulness or Sobbing

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say, or act as if he/she is sad or in low spirits?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say, or Act as if He/She is Sad or in Low Spirits
synonyms: NPI1-Say or Act in Low Spirits

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient put him/herself down or say that he/she feels like a failure?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Put Him/Herself Down or Say That He/She Feels Like a Failure

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say that he/she is a bad person or deserves to be punished?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say That He/She is a Bad Person

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem very discouraged or say that he/she has no future?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem Very Discouraged

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say he/she is a burden to the family or that the family would be better off without him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say He/She is a Burden to the Family

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient express a wish for death or talk about killing himself/herself?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Express a Wish for Death

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of depression or sadness?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Depression or Sadness

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the depression/dysphoria.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Depression/Dysphoria Frequency

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the depression/dysphoria.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Depression/Dysphoria Severity

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Depression/Dysphoria Distress

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Depression/Dysphoria: (frequency score x severity score).
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Depression/Dysphoria FxS Score

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Sub-total of distress score.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - NPI Total Distress Score

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient very nervous, worried, or frightened for no apparent reason? Does he/she seem very tense or fidgety? Is the patient afraid to be apart from you?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Very Nervous, Worried, or Frightened for No Apparent Reason

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say that he/she is worried about planned events?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say That He/She is Worried About Planned Events

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods of feeling shaky, unable to relax, or feeling excessively tense?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods of Feeling Shaky, Unable to Relax, or Feeling Excessively Tense

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods of (or complain of) shortness of breath, gasping, or sighing for no apparent reason other than nervousness?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods of Shortness of Breath, Gasping, or Sighing for No Apparent Reason

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient complain of butterflies in his/her stomach, or of racing or pounding of the heart in association with nervousness? (Symptoms not explained by ill health).
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Complain of Butterflies, Racing or Pounding Heart

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient avoid certain places or situations that make him/her more nervous such as riding in the car, meeting with friends, or being in crowds?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Avoid Certain Places or Situations That Make Him/Her More Nervous

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient become nervous and upset when separated from you (or his/her caregiver)? (Does he/she cling to you to keep from being separated?).
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Become Nervous and Upset When Separated From You

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of anxiety?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Anxiety

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the anxiety.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Anxiety Frequency

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the anxiety.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Anxiety Severity

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Anxiety Distress

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Anxiety: (frequency score x severity score).
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Anxiety FxS Score

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem too cheerful or too happy for no reason? I don't mean the normal happiness that comes from seeing friends, receiving presents, or spending time with family members. I am asking if the patient has a persistent and abnormally good mood or finds humor where others do not.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem Too Cheerful or Too Happy for No Reason

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient appear to feel good or to be too happy, different from his/her usual self?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Appear to Feel Good or to Be Too Happy

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient find humor and laugh at things that others do not find funny?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Fine Humor and Laugh at Things That Others Do Not Find Funny
synonyms: NPI1-Humor Others Do Not Find Funny

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem to have a childish sense of humor with a tendency to giggle or laugh inappropriately (such as when something unfortunate happens to others)?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem to Have a Childish Sense of Humor

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient tell jokes or make remarks that are not funny to others but seem funny to him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Tell Jokes or Make Remarks That are Not Funny to Others
synonyms: NPI1-Jokes Others Do Not Find Funny

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does he/she play childish pranks such as pinching or playing "keep away" for the fun of it?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Play Childish Pranks

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient "talk big" or claim to have more abilities or wealth than is true?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk Big or Claim to Have More Abilities or Wealth Than is True

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of feeling too good or being too happy?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Feeling Too Good or Being Too Happy
synonyms: NPI1-Other Signs of Feeling Too Happy

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the elation/euphoria.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Elation/Euphoria Frequency

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the elation/euphoria.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Elation/Euphoria Severity

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - How emotionally distressing do you find this behavior?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Elation/Euphoria Distress

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Elation/Euphoria: (frequency score x severity score).
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Elation/Euphoria FxS Score

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has the patient lost interest in the world around him/her? Has he/she lost interest in doing things or does he/she lack motivation for starting new activities? Is he/she more difficult to engage in conversation or in doing chores? Is the patient apathetic or indifferent?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Lost Interest in the World Around Him/Her

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem less spontaneous and less active than usual?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem Less Spontaneous and Less Active Than Usual

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient less likely to initiate a conversation?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Less Likely Initiate to Initiate a Conversation

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient less affectionate or lacking in emotions when compared to his/her usual self?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Less Affectionate or Lacking in Emotions

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient contribute less to household chores?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Contribute Less to Household Chores

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem less interested in the activities and plans of others?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Less Interested in the Activities and Plans of Others

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has the patient lost interest in friends and family members?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Lost Interest in Friends and Family Members

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient less enthusiastic about his/her usual interests?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Less Enthusiastic About His/Her Usual Interests

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs that he/she doesn't care about doing new things?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs That He/She Doesn't Care About Doing New Things

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the apathy/indifference.

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of loss of control of his/her impulses?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Loss of Control of His/Her Impulses

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs of irritability?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs of Irritability

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient show any other signs that he/she doesn't care about doing new things?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Show Any Other Signs That He/She Doesn't Care About Doing New Things

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe any other unusual things that I haven't asked about?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Any Other Unusual Things That I Haven't Asked About

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe any other unusual sensory experiences?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Any Other Unusual Sensory Experiences

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that others are stealing from him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Others are Stealing From Him/Her

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient pace around the house without apparent purpose?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Pace Around the House Without Apparent Purpose

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that his/her spouse or others are not who they claim to be?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - His/Her Spouse or Others Are Not Who They Claim To Be

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient rapidly change moods from one to another, being fine one minute and angry the next?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Rapidly Change Moods From One to Another

terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods When He/She Refuses to Cooperate

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient repeatedly put on and take off clothing?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Repeatedly Put On and Take Off Clothing

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient engage in repetitive activities such as handling buttons, picking, wrapping string, etc.?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Engage in Repetitive Activities

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have repetitive activities or "habits" that he/she performs over and over?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Repetitive Activities or 'Habits'

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient rummage around opening and unpacking drawers or closets?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Rummage Around Opening and Unpacking Drawers or Closets

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem sad or depressed? Does he/she say that he/she feels sad or depressed?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem Sad or Depressed

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say things to people that are insensitive or hurt their feelings?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say Things to People that are Insensitive

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say, or act as if he/she is sad or in low spirits?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say, or Act as if He/She is Sad or in Low Spirits
terms.submissionValue: NPI1-Say or Act in Low Spirits
synonyms: NPI1-Say or Act in Low Spirits

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe seeing things not seen by others or behave as if he/she is seeing things not seen by others (people, animals, lights, etc.)?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Seeing Things Not Seen by Others
terms.submissionValue: NPI1-See Things Not Seen by Others
synonyms: NPI1-See Things Not Seen by Others

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods of feeling shaky, unable to relax, or feeling excessively tense?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods of Feeling Shaky, Unable to Relax, or Feeling Excessively Tense

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods of (or complain of) shortness of breath, gasping, or sighing for no apparent reason other than nervousness?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods of Shortness of Breath, Gasping, or Sighing for No Apparent Reason

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient shout or curse angrily?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Shout or Curse Angrily

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient slam doors, kick furniture, throw things?

terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Sleep and Nighttime Behavior Disorders Distress

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Frequency of the nighttime behavior.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Sleep and Nighttime Behavior Disorders Frequency

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Severity of the nighttime behavior.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Sleep and Nighttime Behavior Disorders Severity

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient report smelling odors not smelled by others?

terms.submissionValue: NPI1-Smell Odors Others Do Not Smell
synonyms: NPI1-Smell Odors Others Do Not Smell

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that his/her spouse is having an affair?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - His/Her Spouse is Having an Affair

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient stubborn, having to have things his/her way?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Stubborn

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have sudden flashes of anger?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Sudden Flares of Anger

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient take liberties or touch or hug others in a way that is out of character for him/her?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Take Liberties or Touch or Hug Others

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient "talk big" or claim to have more abilities or wealth than is true?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk Big or Claim to Have More Abilities or Wealth Than is True

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient talk openly about very personal or private matters not usually discussed in public?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk Openly About Very Personal or Private Matters

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient talk to people who are not there?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk to People Who Are Not There

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient talk to total strangers as if he/she knew them?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Talk to Total Strangers as if He/She Knew Them

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient describe tastes that are without any known cause?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Describe Tastes That Are Without Any Known Cause

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient have periods of tearfulness or sobbing that seem to indicate sadness?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Periods of Tearfulness or Sobbing

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient seem too cheerful or too happy for no reason? I don't mean the normal happiness that comes from seeing friends, receiving presents, or spending time with family members. I am asking if the patient has a persistent and abnormally good mood or finds humor where others do not.
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Seem Too Cheerful or Too Happy for No Reason

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that television or magazine figures are actually present in the home? (Does he/she try to talk or interact with them?)
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Television or Magazine Figures Are Actually Present In the Home

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Is the patient uncooperative, resistive to help from others?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Uncooperative

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient believe that unwelcome guests are living in his/her house?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Unwelcome Guests are Living in His/Her House

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient wake up at night, dress, and plan to go out thinking that it is morning and time to start the day?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Wake Up at Night, Dress, and Plan to Go Out
terms.submissionValue: NPI1-Wake at Night and Think Morning
synonyms: NPI1-Wake at Night and Think Morning

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient wander, pace or get involved in inappropriate activities at night?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Wander, Pace or Get Involved in Inappropriate Activities at Night

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she gained weight?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Gained Weight

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Has he/she had a loss of weight?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Loss of Weight

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient express a wish for death or talk about killing himself/herself?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Express a Wish for Death

terms.definition: Neuropsychiatric Inventory - Does the patient say that he/she is worried about planned events?
terms.preferredTerm: NPI - Say That He/She is Worried About Planned Events
